DSM-Section II Personality Disorders
As noted above, categorical personality disorders are commonly assessed via clinical interviews and self-reports. The Structured Clinical Interview for DSM-5 Personality Disorders (SCID-5-PD) Structured Clinical Interview for DSM-5 Personality Disorders (SCID-5-PD) is a widely used clinical interview, directly assessing each DSM-IV and and DSM-5 Section II Personality Disorder symptoms. The SCID-5-PD consists of two components: a self-report and a clinical interview. First, clients endorse items that directly represent DSM Criteria A Personality Disorders. Subsequently, the clinician conducts a clinical semi-structured interview based on the client’s symptom endorsements to determine if the diagnostic criteria have been met. The SCID-IV-PD and SCID-5-PD serve as effective instruments for evaluating symptoms of personality disorders and can provide supporting evidence for a personality disorder diagnosis.
Other clinical interviews such as the International Personality Disorder Examination (IPDE; Loranger, 1999 ) focus on six broad functioning domains relevant to personality disorder assessment: work (i. e., employment functioning), self (i. e., stability of self-image), interpersonal relationships relationships (i. e., interpersonal functioning), affect (i. e., emotional or affective experience), reality testing (i. e., personal beliefs), and impulse control (i. e., impulsivity). The IPDE questionnaire and interview reflect collaborative efforts between the World Health Organization ICD-10 and the National Institute of Health with the American Psychiatric Association’s DSM-IV by corresponding with both nosologies. The Structured Interview of Personality Organization—Revised (STIPO-R; Clarkin et al., 2016 ) is a brief psychodynamic measure that dimensionally assesses personality functioning or personality organizations along five domains. The five domains domains describe identity (i. e., the experiences of a consistent self-image), object relations (i. e., interpersonal relationships), defenses (i. e., defensiveness strategies), aggression (i. e., aggression directed at the self or others), and moral values (i. e., capacity for guilt and practicing norms in interpersonal relationships). The domains are rated along two broad personality organizational dimensions: Normal, Neurotic (levels 1 or 2), and borderline (low, middle, or high). Finally, the Personality Disorder Inventory for DSM-IV (PDI-IV; Widiger & Samuel, 2005 ) assesses assesses the ten DSM-IV personality disorders. The PDI-IV is further organized along several thematic content areas, such as attitudes toward self, attitudes toward others, comfort with others, friendships, and relationships, conflict, work and leisure functioning, consideration of social norms, mood, and appearance and perception.
Some clinical interview instruments target specific categorical personality disorders such as the Revised Diagnostic Interview for Borderlines (DIB-R; Zanarini et al., 1989 ). The DIB-R DIB-R is a semi-structured clinical interview specifically designed to assess borderline personality disorder across four areas: affect, cognition, interpersonal relationships, and impulse action patterns (Zanarini et al., 1989 ). While not primarily used for a clinical diagnosis, the DIB-R is useful for evaluating specific features of borderline personality disorder and examining their longitudinal stability over time (Tragesser et al., 2010 ).
There are a variety variety of self-report measures of personality disorder. For example, the Personality Diagnostic Questionnaire 4+ (PDQ-4+; Hyler, 1994 ) is a commonly commonly used screening instrument to directly identify the presence or absence of the ten DSM personality disorders. The Personality Assessment Inventory (PAI; Morey, 2004 ) includes the scales borderline and antisocial features but does not provide comprehensive coverage of personality pathology. Other personality disorder self-report measures assess DSM PD criteria with adaptive and maladaptive personality traits along with assessments of impairment; however, these are separate from the AMPD. For example, the Schedule for Nonadaptive and Adaptive Personality (SNAP; Clark, 1993 ) is a self and informant report of adaptive personality traits or characteristics related to personality pathology, which includes 15 primary traits across three higher-ordered domains: Negative Temperament, Positive Temperament, and Disinhibition. Trait profiles have been shown to to capture DSM-5-TR personality disorders including avoidant, borderline, obsessive-compulsive, and schizotypal (Wilt et al., 2010 ). Next, the OMNI Personality Inventory (OMNI; Loranger, 2001 ) is a self-report assessment of adaptive and maladaptive personality traits but subscales can be organized to identify the 10 DSM-IV personality disorders and five personality disorder scales (e. g., agreeableness, conscientiousness, extraversion, narcissism, neuroticism, openness, and sensation seeking). The abbreviated version, the OMNI Personality Disorder Inventory (OMNI-IV; Loranger, 2001 ) only assesses for DSM-IV personality disorders. The Millon Clinical Multiaxial Inventory (MCMI-IV) Millon Clinical Multiaxial Inventory (MCMI-IV) is a self-report assessment that evaluates adaptive and maladaptive personality features and psychopathology. It operates under the theoretical framework that personality disorders are evolutionarily based adaptations or maladaptations (Millon et al., 2015 ). The MCMI-IV includes 15 personality-related subscales to measure clinical personality disorder features and ten psychopathology subscales across three general patterns: typical typical functioning, abnormal traits, and disordered.
Finally, the Multi-source Assessment of Personality Pathology (MAPP; Oltmanns & Turkheimer, 2006 ) formerly known known as the Peer Nomination Inventory is a self and informant report measure of DSM-IV personality features and personality traits. Informant reports are a key component of this assessment as individuals with a personality disorder may experience impairment in describing themselves or may avoid endorsing behaviors or personality traits that are less socially desirable (Oltmanns & Turkheimer, 2006 ).
DSM-Section III Alternative Model of Personality Disorders
The Alternative Model of Personality Disorders (AMPD) Alternative Model of Personality Disorders (AMPD) includes instruments to evaluate maladaptive personality traits (Criteria B) and personality functioning (Criteria A). For example, the SCID-5-AMPD (Bender et al., 2018 ; Skodol et al., 2018 ) is a clinical interview designed designed to evaluate Criteria A and B of the AMPD, along with the six personality disorders retained from DSM-5 Section II Personality Disorders (i. e., antisocial, borderline, narcissistic, schizotypal, avoidant, and obsessive-compulsive PDs). The SCID-5-AMPD can be useful in assessing maladaptive personality traits and severity with a dimensional lens that bypasses the pitfalls of the categorical model.
The AMPD also can be assessed through through self-report measures. For example, the Levels of Personality Functioning Scale (LPFS; Morey et al., 2013 ) measures Criteria A of the AMPD which is the degree of impairment in interpersonal (intimacy and empathy) and intrapersonal (identity, self-direction) domains. Additionally, the Personality Inventory for DSM-5 (PID-5; Krueger et al., 2012 ) is a widely used self-report of the AMPD maladaptive personality trait domains (i. e., negative affectivity, detachment, psychoticism, antagonism, and disinhibition), closely related to the Five Factor Model broad domains. Both self-report instruments of the the AMPD can be used concurrently to screen screen for PD pathology.
Five-Factor Model of Personality Disorders
The Five-Factor Model (FFM) Five-Factor Model (FFM) is a widely accepted framework for understanding general personality traits, defining five broad domains and 30 facets along a bipolar dimension. Researchers advocating for a dimensional structure of personality disorders recognize that extreme representations of adaptive personality traits, either high or low, may be understood as maladaptive personality trait variants (Widiger et al., 2012 ). Studies have demonstrated that the FFM can capture symptoms outlined in both the DSM-5 and DSM-IV Personality Disorders. This recognition led to the the development of the Five-Factor Model of Personality Disorders (FFMPD), primarily assessed via self-report measures. FFMPD scales aim to assess DSM-5 Section II Personality disorders through through the lens of the Five-Factor Model. Several FFMPD scales have been developed for personality disorders (Bagby & Widiger, 2018 ) with the exception of paranoid personality disorder. The FFMPD scales can be useful in clinical contexts for assessing maladaptive personality traits relevant to to each of the DSM-5-TR Section II Personality Disorders.
Comprehensive Assessment of Traits Relevant to Personality Disorder Model
The Computerized Adaptive Test of Personality Disorder (CAT-PD; Simms et al., 2011 ), also known as the Comprehensive Assessment of Traits Relevant to Personality Disorders Model Comprehensive Assessment of Traits Relevant to Personality Disorders Model (Ringwald et al., 2023 ), represents an early initiative toward adopting a dimensional model of personality disorders. The CAT-PD instrument aims to comprehensively assess personality traits relevant relevant to personality pathology from a large pool of test items. The CAT-PD model conceptualizes five personality domains: Negative Emotionality, Positive Emotionality, Antagonism, Disconstraint, and Oddity. The presentation of items is dependent upon the client’s responses to items that measure traits relevant to personality pathology. Efficiency stands out as the primary strength of CAT-PD. Additionally, the CAT-PD offers a static test form, serving as a a
standard standard self-report measure.
Hierarchical Taxonomy of Psychopathology
Relevant to personality personality pathology, HiTOP conceptualizes Spectra (e. g., Internalizing, Thought Disorder, Disinhibited Externalizing, Antagonistic Externalizing, Detachment, and Somatoform) related to maladaptive personality trait variants, and psychopathologies included in in the DSM-5-TR. The HiTOP Digital Assessment and Tracker (HiTOP-DAT) is a freely available battery of self-report instruments that assess HiTOP-consistent constructs (
https://​www.​hitop-system.​org/​clinical-tools
), which which can be used freely, and includes a manual and online training materials. This collection of instruments can be useful in identifying maladaptive personality traits as they relate to personality disorders and other psychiatric disorders, through a dimensional lens. The HiTOP-DAT was developed to be an interim step in HiTOP assessment to fill the gap until HiTOP-specific measures could be developed. International Classification of Diseases-11 Personality Disorders
The International Classification of Diseases-11 (ICD-11; World Health Organization, 2019 ) Personality Personality
Disorder Disorder model proposes a dimensional model, departing from the previous ICD categorical approach. Comparatively, this is one step ahead of the DSM model, since the AMPD was placed in Section III Emerging Measures and Models. Nevertheless, the AMPD and ICD-11 personality disorders are closely aligned, sharing several components such as a focus on general dysfunction and maladaptive personality traits. Unlike the DSM-AMPD, no structured clinical interviews assess the ICD-11 PD (Pan & Wang, 2024 ) but several self-report forms have been developed.
The ICD-11 PD model model measures general severity across self and interpersonal functioning domains, measured by the Standardized Assessment of Severity of Personality Disorder (SASPD; Olajide et al., 2018 ). Additionally, the Personality Inventory for ICD-11 (PiCD; Oltmanns & Widiger, 2018 ) measures maladaptive personality traits across five domains—negative affectivity, detachment, dissocial, disinhibition, and anankastic. Similar to the AMPD, there are several self-report measures to assess maladaptive personality traits and functioning, including the ICD-11 Personality Personality Disorder Severity Scale (PDS-ICD-11; Bach & Mulder, 2022 ), a brief measure of personality disorder severity, or the Personality Inventory for DSM-5 Brief Form Plus (PID5 BF+; Bach & Mulder, 2022 ), which assesses maladaptive maladaptive personality traits from both the AMPD and ICD-11 models.
